Description: Terracotta figure of robed man. Flat mould-made ‘Asiatic’, or ‘Assyrian’ man. Pressed into one-piece mould. Torso only (head lost), upper body of terracotta male figure with right arm across chest. Robe is scalloped, garment with dentate fringe, painted red. Cypriot yellow-buff marl clay with abundant coarse black, red and white inclusions.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Context Φ15
Curator's comments: Similar figure as BM 1911,0710.101 and 102, though here only the torso remains. See BM/Big 50126-50127 (BM 1911,0710.101-102) and BM1949,0808.1-2 from Naukratis. ‘from a 26th Dynasty context’ along with BM 1911,0710.92-106 and BM1949,0808.1-2 (Bailey 2008, 186). Such ‘Asiatic’ looking male figurines date to between the mid 7th to late 6th centuries BC, with very close parallels from Cyprus, probably from Arsos workshops (Karageorghis 1995, 19-21, Type I(ii) 38. pl. 9.3). Karageorghis argues the ‘Assyrian’ look may coincide with Assyrian domination of Cyprus during the seventh century BC (1995, 21). See BM/Big 50129, 50127, 50128, 50130 (BM 1911, 0710.102, 1911,0710.103, 1911,0710.105) also from Naukratis. This figurine is labelled in pencil TAΦ15 (although the characters are worn, they are clear), designating this as coming from a context within the sanctuary of Aphrodite, from Gardner’s excavations in 1885-1886. Karageorghis, V. 1995. The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus. IV. The Cypro-Archaic Period small male figurines. Nicosia, University of Cyprus.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DA.041) (Phase 3)
